node.title: Minnesota candidate gives speech while in labor
node.description: Video of Erin Maye Quade shows her holding her stomach and pausing, apparently having a contraction, after finishing a sentence of her speech. She then left, withdrawing from the nomination process.
node.content: ["A Minnesota State Senate candidate was in labor while giving a speech at a convention to secure her party's nomination and had to leave early to give birth. Erin Maye Quade went into labor at about 2 a.m. on Saturday, the morning of Minnesota Democratic-Farmer-Labor Party convention. She still showed up in labor and gave her speech, her campaign manager Mitchell Walstad told CBS News. \u00a0", "Video taken at the convention shows her holding her stomach and pausing, apparently having a contraction, after finishing a sentence of her speech.", "Quade needed to win the endorsement of the party \u2014 the state equivalent of the Democratic Party \u2014 at its convention to officially become its nominee.\u00a0", "Today in Minnesota, @ErinMayeQuade gave a convention speech while in active labor.  And her opponent didn\u2019t think to ask to postpone the convention as she, you know, had to go to the hospital to deliver her baby. What the hell. pic.twitter.com/Wmu5fh40I6", "At the convention, there are multiple rounds of voting, where delegates who sign up to attend the convention chose a nominee. When a candidate reaches 60% of the votes, they receive the party's endorsement, Walstad said.", "\"After the first round of balloting, Erin was at the point where she could not stay anymore, and she chose to withdraw,\" he said. \"She was not forced out, but she chose to [leave] because with endorsing process, there's often a lot of change that can happen between one ballot and the next, and a lot of persuasion can happen if there's no decided candidate after that first round.\"", "Candidates continue to campaign between votes, but Walstad said Maye Quade felt she couldn't meaningfully meet with delegates and accurately present herself through the process.", "Maye Quade asked her opponent, Justin Emmerich, if he would suspend balloting and go to a primary after the first ballots were cast, Walstad told CBS News. Emmerich did not agree to move the voting to a later date.", "When she left, delegates could vote for her Emmerich or the \"no delegate\" option. Emmerich won the nomination with 71% of the votes.\u00a0", "Walstad said the day was \"chaotic.\"\u00a0", "\"I called her at like 6 in the morning [on Saturday], she was in labor, and it was a conversation of like, 'I don't know if I can do this. I don't know if I can be there. I don't know if I can make it through that long of a period of time without having contractions. I don't think I want to have contractions in front of people,'\" he said.", "\"To say I didn't know how to respond would be an understatement,\" Walstad continued. \"I encouraged her to do what she needed to for herself.\"\u00a0", "Maye Quade's wife, Alyse Maye Quade, is the political and organizing director for the party. She posted about the birth of their daughter, Harriet Blake Maye Quade on Sunday, 10 days earlier than her due date.\u00a0", "\"Mom did awesome, even in the moments that got a little intense, and especially when it came to pushing baby girl out,\" she wrote. \"Actually seeing the power and determination, push after push - I'll never look at my wife the same again, she is so powerful.\"\u00a0", "Caitlin O'Kane is a digital content producer covering trending stories for CBS News and its good news brand, The Uplift."]
